diagrams.description: Entrepreneurship's evolution reflects changing economic paradigms and innovation drivers. The Industrial Revolution (1760s-1840s) sparked manufacturing entrepreneurship. Joseph Schumpeter's theory of creative destruction (1942) formalized entrepreneurial economics. Silicon Valley emerged in the 1950s-1960s as a technology entrepreneurship hub. The personal computer revolution of the 1970s-1980s democratized technology ventures. The dot-com boom (1995-2000) created internet entrepreneurship, followed by the bust that taught valuation lessons. The lean startup methodology emerged in 2008, emphasizing rapid iteration and customer validation. The smartphone era (2010s) enabled mobile-first businesses and the gig economy. Today's entrepreneurship integrates AI, blockchain, sustainability focus, and global remote teams.

    1942 : Creative Destruction Theory

    1950s-1960s : Silicon Valley Birth
                : Tech entrepreneurship hub
    1970s-1980s : PC Revolution
                : Technology democratization
    1995-2000 : Dot-com Boom & Bust

    2008 : Lean Startup Methodology
         : Rapid iteration emphasis
    2010s : Mobile & Gig Economy
          : Smartphone-enabled ventures
    2015 : Unicorn Era
         : Billion-dollar startups
    2020s : AI & Sustainability
          : Tech-driven impact ventures
